pros: - For juniors and foreigners looking for a starting career in Singapore, this company is a good stepping stone. It is rare to see at least 3rd generation Singaporean in this company's IT and engineering division. If there are any Singaporeans, they are foreigners who had converted to Singaporean. - Promotion is based on both seniority and pleasing the management / French people rather than merits / skills. The effect is brilliant people leave after about 2-3 years of working and those in technical and management roles are filled with the average or bad ones. - Turnover rate is high and this company even gives 2000 SGD for a successful candidate hiring recommendation, close to what this company gives for a successful patent (1000-1500 EUR). - There are several high-ego managers and toxic colleagues. Sabotage and backstabbing do exist and you will be hardly be able to protect yourself when dealing with these toxic people. See the above 2 points on why this is happening. - Most French colleagues I have worked with are cunning, self-entitled, and arrogant towards Asian. It is hard to identify this since they always appear as very friendly. - Politics are strong in higher managements, especially if it is related to French people. - Not many brilliant people to work with and the experts' expertise are questionable. This is a cybersecurity company focused on applied cryptography and yet, most people inside do not have strong cryptography knowledge. - Health insurance coverages are average.

Tool chains are old, not leveraging modern tools available today. Current tool chains often meet our needs only due to a corruption of the original requirements or a hacking of the tool chain itself. review_title: Good to pick up skills, but progression and promotion are poor
pros:
- Skills - If you are wanting to pick up new skills in optics, electronics, mechanics within a live manufacturing facility, this place is pretty good. You can learn a lot from the experiences they can offer.

- People - There are some very clever people here. You can learn a lot from what they know.

- Work to life balance - Good work to life balance where you can work 4 days a week and have very flexible start and finish times.

The truth here, is that if you are looking for a decent job with little stress this ticks the box. 

If you are looking for something to challenge yourself, this place is only good short term in my eyes. 

There will always be defence work issued by the government and therefore Thales UK will always offer employment. 

However, defence is not very dynamic, therefore there is little scope to change what you do over time.
cons:
- Culture - The onsite culture at the Glasgow site is highly political. It makes it hard to get work done efficiently and in an enjoyable manner. The level of politics is underscored by the number of site staff that are relatives of one and other.

- The culture across Thales UK is non existent. This is partly due to a large French company acquiring a lot of local UK based firms and telling them to operate as a single UK business unit.

- Progression - Progression is slow in terms of pay and grades for engineers. This is better for people who work in business. This was emphasised by recent hires that I was managing on higher wages than me. 

- High resistance to change - There is a good standard of engineering and process, but changing things is especially difficult. This is emphasised by the number of young people who leave the business as new job opportunities need to be fought for.

- Internal Hierarchy - Thales are a French company. The French element of Thales receive better benefits like access to shares, and better pay. This is a slap in the face where the company slogan is "one team, one Thales". It obviously is not.
